Federated Learning under Heterogeneous and Correlated Client Availability

Angelo Rodio1, Francescomaria Faticanti1, Othmane Marfoq12, Giovanni Neglia1, Emilio Leonardi3 This research was supported by the French government through the 3IA CÃ´te dâ€™Azur Investments in the Future project by the National Research Agency (ANR) with reference ANR-19-P3IA-0002, and by Groupe La Poste, sponsor of Inria Foundation, in the framework of FedMalin Inria Challenge.A first version of this work has been accepted at IEEE INFOCOM 2023. 1Inria, UniversitÃ© CÃ´te dâ€™Azur, France. Abstract

The enormous amount of data produced by mobile and IoT devices has motivated the development of federated learning (FL), a framework allowing such devices (or clients) to collaboratively train machine learning models without sharing their local data. FL algorithms (like FedAvg) iteratively aggregate model updates computed by clients on their own datasets. Clients may exhibit different levels of participation, often correlated over time and with other clients. This paper presents the first convergence analysis for a FedAvg-like FL algorithm under heterogeneous and correlated client availability. Our analysis highlights how correlation adversely affects the algorithmâ€™s convergence rate and how the aggregation strategy can alleviate this effect at the cost of steering training toward a biased model. Guided by the theoretical analysis, we propose CA-Fed, a new FL algorithm that tries to balance the conflicting goals of maximizing convergence speed and minimizing model bias. To this purpose, CA-Fed dynamically adapts the weight given to each client and may ignore clients with low availability and large correlation. Our experimental results show that CA-Fed achieves higher time-average accuracy and a lower standard deviation than state-of-the-art AdaFed and F3AST, both on synthetic and real datasets.

Index Terms:
Federated Learning, Distributed Optimization.

I Introduction

The enormous amount of data generated by mobile and IoT devices motivated the emergence of distributed machine learning training paradigmsÂ [1, 2]. Federated Learning (FL)Â [3, 4, 5, 6] is an emerging framework where geographically distributed devices (or clients) participate in the training of a shared Machine Learning (ML) model without sharing their local data. FL was proposed to reduce the overall cost of collecting a large amount of data as well as to protect potentially sensitive usersâ€™ private information. In the original Federated Averaging algorithm (FedAvg)Â [4], a central server selects a random subset of clients from the set of available clients and broadcasts them the shared model. The sampled clients perform a number of independent Stochastic Gradient Descent (SGD) steps over their local datasets and send their local model updates back to the server. Then, the server aggregates the received client updates to produce a new global model, and a new training round begins. At each iteration of FedAvg, the server typically samples randomly a few hundred devices to participateÂ [7, 8].

In real-world scenarios, the availability/activity of clients is dictated by exogenous factors that are beyond the control of the orchestrating server and hard to predict. For instance, only smartphones that are idle, under charge, and connected to broadband networks are commonly allowed to participate in the training processÂ [4, 9]. These eligibility requirements can make the availability of devices correlated over time and space [7, 10, 11, 12]. For example, temporal correlation may origin from a smartphone being under charge for a few consecutive hours and then ineligible for the rest of the day. Similarly, the activity of a sensor powered by renewable energy may depend on natural phenomena intrinsically correlated over time (e.g., solar light). Spatial correlation refers instead to correlation across different clients, which often emerges as consequence of usersâ€™ different geographical distribution. For instance, clients in the same time zone often exhibit similar availability patterns, e.g., due to time-of-day effects.

Temporal correlation in the data sampling procedure is known to negatively affect the performance of ML training even in the centralized settingÂ [13, 14] and can potentially lead to catastrophic forgetting: the data used during the final training phases can have a disproportionate effect on the final model, â€œerasingâ€ the memory of previously learned informationÂ [15, 16]. Catastrophic forgetting has also been observed in FL, where clients in the same geographical area have more similar local data distributions and clientsâ€™ participation follows a cyclic daily pattern (leading to spatial correlation)Â [7, 10, 11, 17]. Despite this evidence, a theoretical study of the convergence of FL algorithms under both temporally and spatially correlated client participation is still missing.

This paper provides the first convergence analysis of FedAvgÂ [4] under heterogeneous and correlated client availability. We assume that clientsâ€™ temporal and spatial availability follows an arbitrary finite-state Markov chain: this assumption models a realistic scenario in which the activity of clients is correlated and, at the same time, still allows the analytical tractability of the system. Our theoretical analysis (i)Â quantifies the negative effect of correlation on the algorithmâ€™s convergence rate through an additional term, which depends on the spectral properties of the Markov chain; (ii)Â points out a trade-off between two conflicting objectives: slow convergence to the optimal model, or fast convergence to a biased model, i.e., a model that minimizes an objective function different from the initial target. Guided by insights from the theoretical analysis, we propose CA-Fed, an algorithm which dynamically assigns weights to clients and achieves a good trade-off between maximizing convergence speed and minimizing model bias. Interestingly, CA-Fed can decide to ignore clients with low availability and high temporal correlation. Our experimental results demonstrate that excluding such clients is a simple, but effective approach to handle the heterogeneous and correlated client availability in FL. Indeed, while CA-Fed achieves a comparable maximum accuracy as the state-of-the-art methods F3ASTÂ [18] and AdaFedÂ [19], its test accuracy exhibits higher time-average and smaller variability over time.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. SectionÂ II describes the problem of correlated client availability in FL and discusses the main related works. SectionÂ III provides a convergence analysis of FedAvg under heterogeneous and correlated client participation. CA-Fed, our correlation-aware FL algorithm, is presented in SectionÂ IV. We evaluate CA-Fed in SectionÂ V, comparing it with state-of-the-art methods on synthetic and real-world data. SectionÂ VII concludes the paper.

In some large-scale FL applications, like training Google keyboard next-word prediction models, each client participates in training at most for one round. The orchestrator usually selects a few hundred clients at each round for a few thousand rounds (e.g., seeÂ [5, TableÂ 2]), but the available set of clients may include hundreds of millions of Android devices. In this scenario, it is difficult to address the potential bias unless there is some a-priori information about each clientâ€™s availability. Anyway, FL can be used by service providers with access to a much smaller set of clients (e.g., smartphone users that have installed a specific app). In this case, a client participates multiple times in training: the orchestrating server may keep track of each clientâ€™s availability and try to compensate for the potentially dangerous heterogeneity in their participation.

Much previous effort on federated learningÂ [4, 22, 23, 24, 25, 17, 19, 18] considered this problem and, under different assumptions on the clientsâ€™ availability (i.e., on (At)t>0subscriptsubscriptğ´ğ‘¡ğ‘¡0\left(A_{t}\right)_{t>0}), designed aggregation strategies that unbias Î”tsubscriptÎ”ğ‘¡\Delta_{t} through an appropriate choice of ğ’’ğ’’\bm{q}. ReferenceÂ [22] provides the first analysis of FedAvg on non-iid data under clientsâ€™ partial participation. Their analysis covers both the case when active clients are sampled uniformly at random without replacement from ğ’¦ğ’¦\mathcal{K} and assigned aggregation weights equal to their target importance (as assumed inÂ [4]), and the case when active clients are sampled iid with replacement from ğ’¦ğ’¦\mathcal{K} with probabilities ğœ¶ğœ¶\bm{\alpha} and assigned equal weights (as assumed inÂ [23]). However, referencesÂ [4, 22, 23] ignore the variance induced by the clients stochastic availability. The authors ofÂ [24] reduce such variance by considering only the clients with important updates, as measured by the value of their norm. ReferencesÂ [17] andÂ [25] reduce the aggregation variance through clustered and soft-clustered sampling, respectively.

Some recent worksÂ [19, 18, 26] do not actively pursue the optimization of the unbiased objective. Instead, they derive bounds for the convergence error and propose heuristics to minimize those bounds, potentially introducing some bias. Our work follows a similar development: we compare our algorithm withÂ F3AST fromÂ [18] andÂ AdaFed fromÂ [19].

The novelty of our study is in considering the spatial and temporal correlation in clientsâ€™ availability dynamics. As discussed in the introduction, such correlations are also introduced by clientsâ€™ eligibility criteria, e.g., smartphones being under charge and connected to broadband networks. The effect of correlation has been ignored until now, probably due to the additional complexity in studying FL algorithmsâ€™ convergence. To the best of our knowledge, the only exception isÂ [18], which scratches the issue of spatial correlation by proposing two different algorithms for the case when clientsâ€™ availabilities are uncorrelated and for the case when they are positively correlated (there is no smooth transition from one algorithm to the other as a function of the degree of correlation).

The effect of temporal correlation on centralized stochastic gradient methods has been addressed inÂ [14, 13, 27, 12]: these works study a variant of stochastic gradient descent where samples are drawn according to a Markov chain. ReferenceÂ [12] extends its analysis to a FL setting where each client draws samples according to a Markov chain. In contrast, our work does not assume a correlation in the data sampling but rather in the clientâ€™s availability. Nevertheless, some of our proof techniques are similar to those used in this line of work and, in particular, we rely on some results inÂ [14].

III Analysis

III-A Main assumptions

We consider a time-slotted system where a slot corresponds to one FL communication round. We assume that clientsâ€™ availability over the timeslots tâˆˆâ„•ğ‘¡â„•t\in\mathbb{N} follows a discrete-time Markov chain (At)tâ‰¥0subscriptsubscriptğ´ğ‘¡ğ‘¡0(A_{t})_{t\geq 0}.222 In SectionÂ III-D we will focus on the case where this chain is the superposition of Nğ‘N independent Markov chains, one for each client.

Assumption 1.

The Markov chain (At)tâ‰¥0subscriptsubscriptğ´ğ‘¡ğ‘¡0(A_{t})_{t\geq 0} on the finite state space [M]delimited-[]ğ‘€[M] is time-homogeneous, irreducible, and aperiodic. It has transition matrix ğğ\bm{P} and stationary distribution ğ›‘ğ›‘\bm{\pi}.

Markov chains have already been used in the literature to model the dynamics of stochastic networks where some nodes or edges in the graph can switch between active and inactive statesÂ [28, 29]. The previous Markovian assumption, while allowing a great degree of flexibility, still guarantees the analytical tractability of the system. The distance dynamics between current and stationary distribution of the Markov process can be characterized by the spectral properties of its transition matrix ğ‘·ğ‘·\bm{P}Â [30]. Let Î»2â€‹(ğ‘·)subscriptğœ†2ğ‘·\lambda_{2}(\bm{P}) denote the the second largest eigenvalue of ğ‘·ğ‘·\bm{P} in absolute value. Previous worksÂ [14] have shown that:

In our analysis, we make the following additional assumptions. Let ğ’˜âˆ—,ğ’˜Bâˆ—superscriptğ’˜superscriptsubscriptğ’˜ğµ\bm{w}^{*},\bm{w}_{B}^{*} denote the minimizers of Fğ¹F and FBsubscriptğ¹ğµF_{B} on Wğ‘ŠW, respectively.

Assumption 2.

The hypothesis class Wğ‘ŠW is convex, compact, and contains in its interior the minimizers ğ°âˆ—,ğ°Bâˆ—,ğ°kâˆ—superscriptğ°superscriptsubscriptğ°ğµsuperscriptsubscriptğ°ğ‘˜\bm{w}^{*},\bm{w}_{B}^{*},\bm{w}_{k}^{*}.

The following assumptions concern clientsâ€™ local objective functions {Fk}kâˆˆğ’¦subscriptsubscriptğ¹ğ‘˜ğ‘˜ğ’¦\{F_{k}\}_{k\in\mathcal{K}}. Assumptions 3 and 4 are standard in the literature on convex optimization [31, Sections 4.1, 4.2]. Assumption 5 is a standard hypothesis in the analysis of federated optimization algorithms [8, SectionÂ 6.1].

Assumption 3 (L-smoothness).

The local functions {Fk}k=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ¹ğ‘˜ğ‘˜1ğ‘\{F_{k}\}_{k=1}^{N} have L-Lipschitz continuous gradients: Fkâ€‹(ğ¯)â‰¤Fkâ€‹(ğ°)+âŸ¨âˆ‡Fkâ€‹(ğ°),ğ¯âˆ’ğ°âŸ©+L2â€‹âˆ¥ğ¯âˆ’ğ°âˆ¥22subscriptğ¹ğ‘˜ğ¯subscriptğ¹ğ‘˜ğ°âˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘˜ğ°ğ¯ğ°ğ¿2superscriptsubscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ¯ğ°22F_{k}(\bm{v})\leq F_{k}(\bm{w})+\langle\nabla F_{k}(\bm{w}),\bm{v}-\bm{w}\rangle+\frac{L}{2}\left\lVert\bm{v}-\bm{w}\right\rVert_{2}^{2}, âˆ€ğ¯,ğ°âˆˆWfor-allğ¯ğ°ğ‘Š\forall\bm{v},\bm{w}\in W.

Assumption 4 (Strong convexity).

The local functions {Fk}k=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ¹ğ‘˜ğ‘˜1ğ‘\{F_{k}\}_{k=1}^{N} are Î¼ğœ‡\mu-strongly convex: Fkâ€‹(ğ¯)â‰¥Fkâ€‹(ğ°)+âŸ¨âˆ‡Fkâ€‹(ğ°),ğ¯âˆ’ğ°âŸ©+Î¼2â€‹âˆ¥ğ¯âˆ’ğ°âˆ¥22,âˆ€ğ¯,ğ°âˆˆWformulae-sequencesubscriptğ¹ğ‘˜ğ¯subscriptğ¹ğ‘˜ğ°âˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘˜ğ°ğ¯ğ°ğœ‡2superscriptsubscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ¯ğ°22for-allğ¯ğ°ğ‘ŠF_{k}(\bm{v})\geq F_{k}(\bm{w})+\langle\nabla F_{k}(\bm{w}),\bm{v}-\bm{w}\rangle+\frac{\mu}{2}\left\lVert\bm{v}-\bm{w}\right\rVert_{2}^{2},~{}\forall\bm{v},\bm{w}\in W.

Assumption 5 (Bounded variance).

III-B Main theorems

TheoremÂ 1 (proof in Appendix -A) decomposes the error of the target global objective as the sum of an optimization error for the biased global objective and a bias error.

Theorem 1 (Decomposing the total error).

Under AssumptionsÂ 2â€“4, the optimization error of the target global objective Ïµ=Fâ€‹(ğ°)âˆ’Fâˆ—italic-Ïµğ¹ğ°superscriptğ¹\epsilon=F(\bm{w})-F^{*} can be bounded as follows:

Ïµâ‰¤2â€‹Îº2â€‹(FBâ€‹(ğ’˜)âˆ’FBâˆ—)âŸâ‰”Ïµopt+2â€‹Îº4â€‹Ï‡ğœ¶âˆ¥ğ’‘2â€‹Î“âŸâ‰”Ïµbias,italic-ÏµsubscriptâŸ2superscriptğœ…2subscriptğ¹ğµğ’˜superscriptsubscriptğ¹ğµâ‰”absentsubscriptitalic-ÏµoptsubscriptâŸ2superscriptğœ…4subscriptsuperscriptğœ’2conditionalğœ¶ğ’‘Î“â‰”absentsubscriptitalic-Ïµbias\displaystyle\epsilon\leq\underbrace{2\kappa^{2}(F_{B}(\bm{w})-F_{B}^{*})\vphantom{\chi^{2}_{\bm{\alpha}\parallel\bm{p}}}}_{\coloneqq\epsilon_{\text{opt}}}+\underbrace{2\kappa^{4}\chi^{2}_{\bm{\alpha}\parallel\bm{p}}\Gamma}_{\coloneqq\epsilon_{\text{bias}}}, (10)

where Îºâ‰”L/Î¼â‰”ğœ…ğ¿ğœ‡\kappa\coloneqq{L}/{\mu}, and Ï‡ğ›‚âˆ¥ğ©2â‰”âˆ‘k=1N(Î±kâˆ’pk)2/pkâ‰”subscriptsuperscriptğœ’2conditionalğ›‚ğ©superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜2subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜\chi^{2}_{\bm{\alpha}\parallel\bm{p}}\coloneqq\sum_{k=1}^{N}{(\alpha_{k}-p_{k})^{2}}/{p_{k}}.

TheoremÂ 2 below proves that the optimization error Ïµoptsubscriptitalic-Ïµopt\epsilon_{\text{opt}} associated to the biased objective FBsubscriptğ¹ğµF_{B}, evaluated on the trajectory determined by schemeÂ (3), asymptotically vanishes. The non-vanishing bias error Ïµbiassubscriptitalic-Ïµbias\epsilon_{\text{bias}} captures the discrepancy between Fâ€‹(ğ’˜)ğ¹ğ’˜F(\bm{w}) and FBâ€‹(ğ’˜)subscriptğ¹ğµğ’˜F_{B}(\bm{w}). This latter term depends on the chi-square divergence Ï‡ğœ¶âˆ¥ğ’‘2subscriptsuperscriptğœ’2conditionalğœ¶ğ’‘\chi^{2}_{\bm{\alpha}\parallel\bm{p}} between the target and biased probability distributions ğœ¶=(Î±k)kâˆˆğ’¦ğœ¶subscriptsubscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜ğ‘˜ğ’¦\bm{\alpha}=(\alpha_{k})_{k\in\mathcal{K}} and ğ’‘=(pk)kâˆˆğ’¦ğ’‘subscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘˜ğ’¦\bm{p}=(p_{k})_{k\in\mathcal{K}}, and on Î“Î“\Gamma, that quantifies the degree of heterogeneity of the local functions. When all local functions are identical (Î“=0Î“0\Gamma=0), the bias term Ïµbiassubscriptitalic-Ïµbias\epsilon_{\text{bias}} also vanishes. For Î“>0Î“0\Gamma>0, the bias error can still be controlled by the aggregation weights assigned to the devices. In particular, the bias term vanishes when qkâˆÎ±k/Ï€k,âˆ€kâˆˆğ’¦formulae-sequenceproportional-tosubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜subscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜for-allğ‘˜ğ’¦q_{k}\propto\alpha_{k}/\pi_{k},\forall k\in\mathcal{K}. Since it asymptotically cancels the bias error, we refer to this choice as unbiased aggregation strategy.

However, in practice, FL training is limited to a finite number of iterations Tğ‘‡T (typically a few hundredsÂ [7, 5]), and the previous asymptotic considerations may not apply. In this regime, the unbiased aggregation strategy can be suboptimal, since the minimization of Ïµbiassubscriptitalic-Ïµbias\epsilon_{\text{bias}} not necessarily leads to the minimization of the total error Ïµâ‰¤Ïµopt+Ïµbiasitalic-Ïµsubscriptitalic-Ïµoptsubscriptitalic-Ïµbias\epsilon\leq\epsilon_{\text{opt}}+\epsilon_{\text{bias}}. This motivates the analysis of the optimization error Ïµoptsubscriptitalic-Ïµopt\epsilon_{\text{opt}}.

TheoremÂ 2 (proof in Appendix -B) proves convergence of the expected biased objective FBsubscriptğ¹ğµF_{B} to its minimum FBâˆ—superscriptsubscriptğ¹ğµF_{B}^{*} under correlated client participation. Our bound (12) captures the effect of correlation through the factor lnâ¡(1/Î»â€‹(ğ‘·))1ğœ†ğ‘·\ln{(1/\lambda(\bm{P}))}: a high correlation worsens the convergence rate. In particular, we found that the numerator ofÂ (12) has a quadratic-over-linear fractional dependence on ğ’’ğ’’\bm{q}. Minimizing Ïµoptsubscriptitalic-Ïµopt\epsilon_{\text{opt}} leads, in general, to a different choice of ğ’’ğ’’\bm{q} than minimizing Ïµbiassubscriptitalic-Ïµbias\epsilon_{\text{bias}}.

III-C Minimizing the total error Ïµâ‰¤Ïµopt+Ïµbiasitalic-Ïµsubscriptitalic-Ïµoptsubscriptitalic-Ïµbias\epsilon\leq{\epsilon}_{\text{opt}}+{\epsilon}_{\text{bias}}

Our analysis points out a trade-off between minimizing Ïµoptsubscriptitalic-Ïµopt\epsilon_{\text{opt}} orÂ Ïµbiassubscriptitalic-Ïµbias\epsilon_{\text{bias}}. Our goal is to find the optimal aggregation weightsÂ ğ’’âˆ—superscriptğ’’\bm{q}^{*} that minimize the upper bound on total error Ïµâ€‹(ğ’’)italic-Ïµğ’’\epsilon(\bm{q}) inÂ (10): {mini} qÏµ_opt(q) + Ïµ_bias(q); \addConstraintq â‰¥0 \addConstraintâˆ¥qâˆ¥1 = Q.

In AppendixÂ -E we prove thatÂ (III-C) is a convex optimization problem, which can be solved with the method of Lagrange multipliers. However, the solution is not of practical utility because the constants inÂ (10) andÂ (12) (e.g., Lğ¿L, Î¼ğœ‡\mu, Î“Î“\Gamma, CPsubscriptğ¶ğ‘ƒC_{P}) are in general problem-dependent and difficult to estimate during training. In particular, Î“Î“\Gamma poses particular difficulties as it is defined in terms of the minimizer of the target objective Fğ¹F, but the FL algorithm generally minimizes the biased function FBsubscriptğ¹ğµF_{B}. Moreover, the bound in (10), similarly to the bound inÂ [32], diverges when setting some qksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜q_{k} equal to 00, but this is simply an artifact of the proof technique. A result of more practical interest is the following (proof in AppendixÂ -C):

Theorem 3 (An alternative decomposition of the total errorÂ Ïµitalic-Ïµ{\epsilon}).

Under the same assumptions of Theorem 1, let Î“â€²â‰”maxkâ¡{Fkâ€‹(ğ°Bâˆ—)âˆ’Fkâˆ—}â‰”superscriptÎ“â€²subscriptğ‘˜subscriptğ¹ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ°ğµsuperscriptsubscriptğ¹ğ‘˜\Gamma^{\prime}\coloneqq\max_{k}\{F_{k}({\bm{w}}_{B}^{*})-F_{k}^{*}\}. The following result holds:

Ïµâ‰¤2â€‹Îº2â€‹(FBâ€‹(ğ’˜)âˆ’FBâˆ—)âŸâ‰”Ïµopt+8â€‹Îº4â€‹dTâ€‹V2â€‹(ğœ¶,ğ’‘)â€‹Î“â€²âŸâ‰”Ïµbiasâ€²,italic-ÏµsubscriptâŸ2superscriptğœ…2subscriptğ¹ğµğ’˜superscriptsubscriptğ¹ğµâ‰”absentsubscriptitalic-ÏµoptsubscriptâŸ8superscriptğœ…4superscriptsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘‡ğ‘‰2ğœ¶ğ’‘superscriptÎ“â€²â‰”absentsuperscriptsubscriptitalic-Ïµbiasâ€²\displaystyle\epsilon\leq\underbrace{2\kappa^{2}(F_{B}(\bm{w})-F_{B}^{*})}_{\coloneqq\epsilon_{\text{opt}}}+\underbrace{8\kappa^{4}d_{TV}^{2}(\bm{\alpha},\bm{p})\Gamma^{\prime}}_{\coloneqq\epsilon_{\text{bias}}^{\prime}}, (13)

where dTâ€‹Vâ€‹(ğ›‚,ğ©)â‰”12â€‹âˆ‘k=1N|Î±kâˆ’pk|â‰”subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘‡ğ‘‰ğ›‚ğ©12superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘subscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜d_{TV}(\bm{\alpha},\bm{p})\coloneqq\frac{1}{2}\sum_{k=1}^{N}\lvert\alpha_{k}-p_{k}\rvert is the total variation distance between the probability distributions ğ›‚ğ›‚\bm{\alpha} and ğ©ğ©\bm{p}.

The new constant Î“â€²superscriptÎ“â€²\Gamma^{\prime} is defined in terms of ğ’˜Bâˆ—superscriptsubscriptğ’˜ğµ\bm{w}_{B}^{*}, and then it is easier to evaluate during training. However, Î“â€²superscriptÎ“â€²\Gamma^{\prime} depends onÂ ğ’’ğ’’\bm{q}, because it is evaluated at the point of minimum of FBsubscriptğ¹ğµF_{B}. This dependence makes the minimization of the right-hand side of (13) more challenging (for example, the corresponding problem is not convex). We study the minimization of the two terms Ïµoptsubscriptitalic-Ïµopt\epsilon_{\text{opt}} andÂ Ïµbiasâ€²subscriptsuperscriptitalic-Ïµâ€²bias\epsilon^{\prime}_{\text{bias}} separately and learn some insights, which we use to design the new FL algorithm CA-Fed.

III-D Minimizing Ïµoptsubscriptitalic-Ïµopt{\epsilon}_{\text{{opt}}}

The minimization of Ïµoptsubscriptitalic-Ïµopt\epsilon_{\text{opt}} is still a convex optimization problem (AppendixÂ -D). In particular, at the optimum non-negative weights are set accordingly to qkâˆ—=aâ€‹(Î»âˆ—â€‹Ï€kâˆ’Î¸âˆ—)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘superscriptğœ†subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜superscriptğœƒq_{k}^{*}=a(\lambda^{*}\pi_{k}-\theta^{*}) with ağ‘a, Î»âˆ—superscriptğœ†\lambda^{*}, and Î¸âˆ—superscriptğœƒ\theta^{*} positive constants (seeÂ (27)). It follows that clients with smaller availability get smaller weights in the aggregation. In particular, this suggests that clients with the smallest availability can be excluded from the aggregation, leading to the following guideline:

Guideline A: to speed up the convergence, we can exclude, i.e., set qkâˆ—=0superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜0q_{k}^{*}=0, the clients with lowest availability Ï€ksubscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜\pi_{k}.

This guideline can be justified intuitively: updates from clients with low participation may be too sporadic to allow the FL algorithm to keep track of their local objectives. They act as a noise slowing down the algorithmâ€™s convergence. It may be advantageous to exclude these clients from participating.

We observe that the choice of the aggregation weights ğ’’ğ’’\bm{q} does not affect the clientsâ€™ availability process and, in particular, Î»â€‹(ğ‘·)ğœ†ğ‘·\lambda(\bm{P}). However, if the algorithm excludes some clients, it is possible to consider the state space of the Markov chain that only specifies the availability state of the remaining clients, and this Markov chain may have different spectral properties. For the sake of concreteness, we consider here (and in the rest of the paper) the particular case when the availability of each client kğ‘˜k evolves according to a two-states Markov chain (Atk)tâ‰¥0subscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ´ğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğ‘¡0(A_{t}^{k})_{t\geq 0} with transition probability matrix ğ‘·ğ’Œsubscriptğ‘·ğ’Œ\bm{P_{k}} and these Markov chains are all independent. In this case, the aggregate process is described by the product Markov chain (At)tâ‰¥0subscriptsubscriptğ´ğ‘¡ğ‘¡0(A_{t})_{t\geq 0} with transition matrix ğ‘·=â¨‚kâˆˆğ’¦ğ‘·ğ’Œğ‘·subscripttensor-productğ‘˜ğ’¦subscriptğ‘·ğ’Œ\bm{P}=\bigotimes_{\scriptstyle k\in\mathcal{K}}\bm{P_{k}} and Î»â€‹(ğ‘·)=maxkâˆˆğ’¦â¡Î»â€‹(ğ‘·ğ’Œ)ğœ†ğ‘·subscriptğ‘˜ğ’¦ğœ†subscriptğ‘·ğ’Œ\lambda(\bm{P})=\max_{\scriptstyle k\in\mathcal{K}}\lambda(\bm{P_{k}}), where ğ‘·ğ’Šâ€‹â¨‚ğ‘·ğ’‹subscriptğ‘·ğ’Štensor-productsubscriptğ‘·ğ’‹\bm{P_{i}}\bigotimes\bm{P_{j}} denotes the Kronecker product between matrices ğ‘·ğ’Šsubscriptğ‘·ğ’Š\bm{P_{i}} and ğ‘·ğ’‹subscriptğ‘·ğ’‹\bm{P_{j}}Â [30, ExerciseÂ 12.6]. In this setting, it is possible to redefine the Markov chain (At)tâ‰¥0subscriptsubscriptğ´ğ‘¡ğ‘¡0(A_{t})_{t\geq 0} by taking into account the reduced state space defined by the clients with a non-null aggregation weight, i.e., ğ‘·â€²=â¨‚kâ€²âˆˆğ’¦â€‹|qkâ€²>â€‹0ğ‘·ğ’Œâ€²superscriptğ‘·bold-â€²subscripttensor-productsuperscriptğ‘˜â€²ğ’¦ketsubscriptğ‘superscriptğ‘˜â€²0subscriptğ‘·superscriptğ’Œbold-â€²\bm{P^{\prime}}=\bigotimes_{\scriptstyle k^{\prime}\in\mathcal{K}|q_{k^{\prime}}>0}\bm{P_{k^{\prime}}} and Î»â€‹(ğ‘·â€²)=maxkâ€²âˆˆğ’¦â€‹|qkâ€²>â€‹0â¡Î»â€‹(ğ‘·ğ’Œâ€²)ğœ†superscriptğ‘·bold-â€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘˜â€²ğ’¦ketsubscriptğ‘superscriptğ‘˜â€²0ğœ†subscriptğ‘·superscriptğ’Œbold-â€²\lambda(\bm{P^{\prime}})=\max_{\scriptstyle k^{\prime}\in\mathcal{K}|q_{k^{\prime}}>0}\lambda(\bm{P_{k^{\prime}}}), which is potentially smaller than the case when all clients participate to the aggregation. These considerations lead to the following guideline:

Guideline B: to speed up the convergence, we can exclude, i.e., set qkâˆ—=0superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜0q_{k}^{*}=0, the clients with largest Î»â€‹(ğğ¤)ğœ†subscriptğğ¤\lambda(\bm{P_{k}}).

Intuition also supports this guideline. Clients with large Î»â€‹(ğ‘·ğ’Œ)ğœ†subscriptğ‘·ğ’Œ\lambda(\bm{P_{k}}) tend to be available or unavailable for long periods of time. Due to the well-known catastrophic forgetting problem affecting gradient methodsÂ [33, 34], these clients may unfairly steer the algorithm toward their local objective when they appear at the final stages of the training period. Moreover, their participation in the early stages may be useless, as their contribution will be forgotten during their long absence. The FL algorithm may benefit from directly neglecting such clients.

We observe that guidelineÂ B strictly applies to this specific setting where clientsâ€™ dynamics are independent (and there is no spatial correlation). We do not provide a corresponding guideline for the case when clients are spatially correlated (we leave this task for future research). However, in this more general setting, it is possible to ignore guidelineÂ B but still draw on guidelinesÂ A andÂ C, or still consider guidelineÂ B if clients are spatially correlated (see discussion in SectionÂ VI-B).

III-E Minimizing Ïµbiasâ€²superscriptsubscriptitalic-Ïµbiasâ€²{\epsilon}_{\text{{bias}}}^{\prime}

The bias error Ïµbiasâ€²subscriptsuperscriptitalic-Ïµâ€²bias\epsilon^{\prime}_{\text{bias}} inÂ  (13) vanishes when the total variation distance between the target importance ğœ¶ğœ¶\bm{\alpha} and the biased importance ğ’‘ğ’‘\bm{p} is zero, i.e., when qkâˆÎ±k/Ï€k,âˆ€kâˆˆğ’¦formulae-sequenceproportional-tosubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜subscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜for-allğ‘˜ğ’¦q_{k}\propto\alpha_{k}/\pi_{k},\forall k\in\mathcal{K}. Then, after excluding the clients that contribute the most to the optimization error and particularly slow down the convergence (guidelines A and B), we can assign to the remaining clients an aggregation weight inversely proportional to their availability, such that the bias error Ïµbiasâ€²superscriptsubscriptitalic-Ïµbiasâ€²{\epsilon}_{\text{{bias}}}^{\prime} is minimized.

Guideline C: to reduce the bias error, we set qkâˆ—âˆÎ±k/Ï€kproportional-tosuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜subscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜q_{k}^{*}\propto\alpha_{k}/\pi_{k} for the clients that are not excluded by the previous guidelines.

IV Proposed Algorithm

GuidelinesÂ A andÂ B in SectionÂ III suggest that the minimization ofÂ Ïµoptsubscriptitalic-Ïµopt\epsilon_{\text{opt}} can lead to the exclusion of some available clients from the aggregation step (3), in particular those with low availability and/or high correlation. For the remaining clients, guidelineÂ C proposes to set their aggregation weight inversely proportional to their availability to reduce the bias errorÂ Ïµbiasâ€²superscriptsubscriptitalic-Ïµbiasâ€²\epsilon_{\text{bias}}^{\prime}. Motivated by these insights, we propose CA-Fed, a client sampling and aggregation strategy that takes into account the problem of correlated client availability in FL, described in AlgorithmÂ 1. CA-Fed learns during training which are the clients to exclude and how to set the aggregation weights of the other clients to achieve a good trade-off betweenÂ Ïµoptsubscriptitalic-Ïµopt\epsilon_{\text{opt}} andÂ Ïµbiasâ€²superscriptsubscriptitalic-Ïµbiasâ€²\epsilon_{\text{bias}}^{\prime}. While guidelinesÂ A andÂ B indicate which clients to remove, the exact number of clients to remove at roundÂ tğ‘¡t is identified by minimizing Ïµ(t)superscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘¡\epsilon^{(t)} as a proxy for the bound inÂ (13):444 FollowingÂ (13), one could reasonably introduce a hyper-parameter to weigh the relative importance of the optimization and bias terms in the sum. We discuss this additional optimization of CA-Fed in SectionÂ VI-A.

IV-C CA-Fedâ€™s computation/communication cost

CA-Fed aims to improve training convergence and not to reduce its computation and communication overhead. Nevertheless, excluding some available clients reduces the overall training cost, as we will discuss in this section referring, for the sake of concreteness, to neural networksâ€™ training.

The available clients not selected for training are only requested to evaluate their local loss on the current model once on a single batch instead than performing Eğ¸E gradient updates, which would require roughly 2Ã—Eâˆ’12ğ¸12\times E-1 more calculations (because of the forward and backward pass). For the selected clients, there is no extra computation cost as computing the loss corresponds to the forward pass they should, in any case, perform during the first local gradient update.

In terms of communication, the excluded clients only transmit the loss, a single scalar, much smaller than the model update. Conversely, participating clients transmit the local loss and the model update. Still, this additional overhead is negligible and likely fully compensated by the communication savings for the excluded clients.

V Experimental Evaluation

V-A Experimental Setup

Federated system simulator

In our experiments, we simulate the clientsâ€™ availability dynamics featuring different levels of temporal correlations. We model the activity of each client as a two-state homogeneous Markov process with state space ğ’®={â€œactiveâ€,â€œinactiveâ€}ğ’®â€œactiveâ€â€œinactiveâ€\mathcal{S}=\{\text{``\emph{active}''},\text{``\emph{inactive}''}\}. In order to simulate the statistical heterogeneity present in the federated learning system, we consider an experimental setting with two disjoint groups of clients Gi,i=1,2formulae-sequencesubscriptğºğ‘–ğ‘–12{G}_{i},~{}i=1,2, to which we associate two different data distributions ğ’«i,i=1,2formulae-sequencesubscriptğ’«ğ‘–ğ‘–12\mathcal{P}_{i},~{}i=1,2, to be precised later. Datasets and models

All experiments are performed on a binary classification synthetic dataset (described in AppendixÂ -F) and on the real-world MNIST datasetÂ [35], using N=24ğ‘24N=24 clients. For MNIST dataset, we introduce statistical heterogeneity across the two groups of clients (i.e., we make the two distributions ğ’«1subscriptğ’«1\mathcal{P}_{1} and ğ’«2subscriptğ’«2\mathcal{P}_{2} different), following the same approach inÂ [36]: 1)Â every client is assigned a random subset of the total training data; 2)Â the data of clients from the second group is modified by randomly swapping two pairs of labels. We maintain the original training/test data split of MNIST and use 20%percent2020\% of the training dataset as validation dataset. We use a linear classifier with a ridge penalization of parameter 10âˆ’2superscript10210^{-2}, which is a strongly convex objective function, for both the synthetic and the real-world MNIST datasets.

V-B Experimental Results

FigureÂ 1 shows the availability of each client during a training run on the synthetic dataset. Clients selected (resp.Â excluded) by CA-Fed are highlighted in black (resp.Â red). We observe that excluded clients tend to be those with low average availability or high correlation.

FigureÂ 2 shows the importance pksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜p_{k} (averaged over time) given by different algorithms to each client kğ‘˜k during a full training run. We observe that all the algorithms, except Unbiased, depart from the target importance ğœ¶ğœ¶\bm{\alpha}. As suggested by guidelinesÂ A andÂ B, CA-Fed tends to favor the group of â€œmore availableâ€ clients, at the expense of the â€œless availableâ€ clients.

FigureÂ 3 shows the time-average accuracy up to roundÂ tğ‘¡t of the learned model averaged over three different runs. On both datasets, CA-Fed achieves the highest accuracy, which is about a percentage point higher than the second best algorithm (F3AST). TableÂ I shows for each algorithm: the average over three runs of the maximum test accuracy achieved during training, the time-average test accuracy achieved during training, together with its standard deviation within the second half of the training period. Results show that while CA-Fed achieves a maximum accuracy which is comparable to the Unbiased baseline and state-of-the-art AdaFed and F3AST, it gets a higher time-average accuracy (1.241.241.24 percentage points) in comparison to the second best (F3AST), and a smaller standard deviation (1.5Ã—1.5\times) in comparison to the second bestÂ (F3AST).

VI Discussion

In this section, we discuss some general concerns and remarks on our algorithm.

VI-A Controlling the number of excluded clients

TheoremsÂ 1 andÂ 3 suggest that the condition number Îº2superscriptğœ…2\kappa^{2} can play a meaningful role in the minimization of the total error Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon. Our algorithm uses a proxy (Ïµ(t)superscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘¡\epsilon^{(t)}) of the total error. To take into account the effect of Îº2superscriptğœ…2\kappa^{2}, we can introduce a hyper-parameter that weights the relative importance of the optimization and bias error inÂ (14):

Ïµâ€²(t)â‰”FBâ€‹(ğ’˜t,0)âˆ’FBâˆ—+ÎºÂ¯2â‹…dTâ€‹V2â€‹(ğœ¶,ğ’‘)â€‹Î“â€².â‰”superscriptsuperscriptitalic-Ïµâ€²ğ‘¡subscriptğ¹ğµsubscriptğ’˜ğ‘¡0superscriptsubscriptğ¹ğµâ‹…superscriptÂ¯ğœ…2superscriptsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘‡ğ‘‰2ğœ¶ğ’‘superscriptÎ“â€²{\epsilon^{\prime}}^{(t)}\coloneqq F_{B}(\bm{w}_{t,0})-F_{B}^{*}+\bar{\kappa}^{2}\cdot d_{TV}^{2}(\bm{\alpha},\bm{p})\Gamma^{\prime}.

A small value of ÎºÂ¯2superscriptÂ¯ğœ…2\bar{\kappa}^{2} penalizes the bias term in favor of the optimization error, resulting in a larger number of clients excluded by CA-Fed. On the other hand, CA-Fed tends to include more clients for a large value of ÎºÂ¯2superscriptÂ¯ğœ…2\bar{\kappa}^{2}. Asymptotically, for ÎºÂ¯2â†’+âˆâ†’superscriptÂ¯ğœ…2\bar{\kappa}^{2}\rightarrow+\infty, CA-Fed reduces to the Unbiased baseline. To further improve the performance of CA-Fed, a finer tuning of the values of ÎºÂ¯2superscriptÂ¯ğœ…2\bar{\kappa}^{2} can be performed.

VI-B CA-Fed in presence of spatial correlation

Although CA-Fed is mainly designed to handle temporal correlation, it does not necessarily perform poorly in presence of spatial correlation, as well.

Consider the following spatially-correlated scenario: clients are grouped in clusters, each cluster câˆˆğ’ğ‘ğ’c\in\mathcal{C} is characterized by an underlying Markov chain, which determines when all clients in the cluster are available/unavailable, the Markov chains of different clusters are independent. Let Î»csubscriptğœ†ğ‘\lambda_{c} denote the second largest eigenvalue in module of cluster-cğ‘câ€™s Markov chain. In this case, one needs to exclude all clients in the cluster cÂ¯=argâ¡maxcâˆˆğ’â¡Î»cÂ¯ğ‘subscriptğ‘ğ’subscriptğœ†ğ‘\bar{c}=\arg\max_{c\in\mathcal{C}}\lambda_{c} to reduce the eigenvalue of the aggregate Markov chain.

In this setting, CA-Fed would associate similar eigenvalue estimates to all clients in the same cluster, then it would correctly start considering for exclusion the clients in cluster cÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\bar{c} and potentially remove sequentially all clients in the same cluster. These considerations suggest that CA-Fed may still operate correctly even in presence of spatial correlation.

VI-C About CA-Fedâ€™s fairness

A strategy that excludes clients from the training phase, such as CA-Fed, may naturally raise fairness concerns. The concept of fairness in FL does not have a unified definition in the literatureÂ [37, Chapter 8]: fairness goals can be captured by a suitable choice of the target weights in (1). For example, per-client fairness can be achieved by setting Î±ksubscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜\alpha_{k} equal for every client, while per-sample fairness by setting Î±ksubscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜\alpha_{k} proportional to the local dataset size |Dk|subscriptğ·ğ‘˜|D_{k}|. If we assume that the global objective inÂ (1) indeed reflects also fairness concerns, then CA-Fed is intrinsically fair, in the sense that it guarantees that the performance objective of the learned model is as close as possible to its minimum value.

VII Conclusion

This paper presented the first convergence analysis for a FedAvg-like FL algorithm under heterogeneous and correlated client availability. The analysis quantifies how correlation adversely affects the algorithmâ€™s convergence rate and highlights a general bias-versus-convergence-speed trade-off. Guided by the theoretical analysis, we proposed CA-Fed, a new FL algorithm that tries to balance the conflicting goals of maximizing convergence speed and minimizing model bias. Our experimental results demonstrate that adaptively excluding clients with high temporal correlation and low availability is an effective approach to handle the heterogeneous and correlated client availability in FL.
